fields.headline: In brief
fields.bodyText: Couples to challenge government ban on Cambodian adoptions Couples who want to adopt Cambodian children will this week contest a government ban on the process. Margaret Hodge, the Children's Minister, suspended adoptions in June last year over concerns that documents were being forged and mothers coerced into giving up their children. Six couples will argue in the High Court of Justice that Hodge did not have the power to impose the ban and abused her position by failing to consult them. The couples say her decision takes no account of Cambodia's humanitarian crisis, in which Unicef estimates there are over 670,000 orphans from a population of just 13 million. 'We have all been approved to adopt Cambodian children,' said Malcolm Dixon, one of the campaigners fighting the ban. 'It's bizarre.' Armed robber escapes prison An armed robber has escaped from an open prison. Darcy William Patrick Whiting, 41, was serving a 17-year sentence when he escaped from Leyhill prison in Gloucestershire on Friday night. Police believe Whiting may be in the Oxford area and have warned the public not to approach him. He was serving a term for armed robbery, possession of a firearm and assault causing actual bodily harm. He is white, 5ft 6in tall with a tattoo which reads 'Darcy' on his left arm. Body may be lost hill walker Rescuers searching for a missing 74-year-old hillwalker found a body yesterday. Scouring the Loch Laggan area of the Scottish Highlands, they came across the remains of an elderly man. The hill walker had been reported overdue from a walk on Beinn a Chlachair late on Friday night. The search effort was hampered by poor weather conditions but a helicopter joined members of Cairngorm Mountain Rescue Team yesterday morning when conditions improved and they found the body. Explosion at plastics factory Two workmen remained in a serious condition after a blast at a Glasgow plastics factory which injured four others. Phil Harrison, 57, and Archie Simpson, 53, were being treated at Glasgow Royal Infirmary. The explosion at the James G Carrick factory came nearly a year after Stockline Plastics in the city collapsed, killing nine people and injuring dozens more. Ocean queens in port The two most famous ocean liners in the world were in their home port of Southampton yesterday. The Cunard Queen Mary 2 and the QE2 have only once been in Southampton together. The Queen Mary 2, which cost £540 million, and is the largest, most expensive passenger ship in history, returned home from a six-month Caribbean season, and the QE2 from her 23rd world cruise. The flagship of the Queen Mary 2 sailed past and saluted the former flagship, QE2, before starting a transatlantic crossing. Oasis tickets snapped up Three thousand tickets that went on sale for four concerts by Oasis completely sold out in an hour. Thousands of fans of Noel and Liam (above) Gallagher jammed phone lines and crashed their website to buy tickets for concerts in London and Edinburgh next month. The band's sixth album is due to be released on 30 May. Sport debate An Observer debate 'Why Doesn't Sport Matter More?' is taking place on Monday 25 April from 7pm to 8.30pm at The Royal Institute of British Architects in London. The event will be chaired by Clare Balding, broadcaster and columnist for The Observer, and on the panel are: Sir Trevor Brooking, from the FA; Richard Caborn MP, sports minister; James Cracknell, double Olympic gold medal-winning oarsman; and Lord Colin Moynihan, Olympic medalist and former sports minister. For tickets, which are £6 including booking fee, call 0870 890 6002.
